title: How to Make Cinnamon Pancakes

steps.headline: Gather your supplies.
steps.description: To make these basic cinnamon pancakes, you will need your ingredients, a medium mixing bowl, a whisk or electric beaters, and a griddle or frying pan.

steps.headline: Heat your frying pan.
steps.description: Add some extra oil or butter to the frying pan to lightly coat the bottom. Heat the oil over medium to high heat while you prepare the batter.

steps.headline: Combine the liquid ingredients.
steps.description:
In your mixing bowl, whisk together the wet ingredients, including the egg or egg replacer. Suitable egg replacers for this recipe include:
2 1/2 tablespoons (37.5 g) ground flaxseed mixed with 3 tablespoons (45 ml) water. 1/2 a mashed or pureed banana. 1 1/2 teaspoons (7.5 g) Ener-G Egg replacer mixed with 2 tablespoons (30 ml) water.

steps.headline: Mix in the dry ingredients.
steps.description: Continue whisking or beating the liquids as you incorporate the dry ingredients. Don’t overmix the batter, or you could end up with chewy pancakes. A few lumps in the batter are acceptable.

steps.headline: Pour the pancakes.
steps.description: Unless you have a large frying pan, make one pancake at a time. Pour a quarter-cup (60 ml) of batter into the frying pan and let it cook. When bubbles begin to form and cover the top side of the pancake, flip it over and cook for another two minutes. You want both sides to be golden brown. Add a bit more oil and repeat until all the pancakes are cooked.

steps.headline: Serve immediately.
steps.description: If you want to wait until all the pancakes are cooked before serving, keep them warm in a warming drawer, on a plate covered in foil, or on a cookie sheet in a low oven.

steps.headline: Gather your supplies.
steps.description: To make this apple and cinnamon pancake topping (which also functions as an apple pie filling or all-purpose dessert topping), you’ll need your apples, a sharp knife, and a large saucepan.

steps.headline: Chop the apples.
steps.description: After coring and peeling the apples, cut them into small cubes. Set them aside as you prepare the sauce.

steps.headline: Combine the sauce ingredients.
steps.description: Add the water, lemon juice, spices, sugar, maple syrup, and cornstarch to the saucepan. Heat on medium heat, stirring frequently. Once the sauce starts to bubble and thicken, continue stirring for another two minutes.

steps.headline: Add the apples and vanilla.
steps.description: Turn the heat to low and stir to combine. Cover the saucepan and let the mixture cook on low for about 10 minutes, until the apples are soft.

steps.headline: Let it cool.
steps.description: Once the apples are soft, remove the filling from the heat and allow it to cool for a few minutes. It doesn’t have to be room temperature, but you don’t want to burn any mouths!

steps.headline: Serve over pancakes.
steps.description: Place one to two pancakes on a plate and cover each one with a few dollops of the apple cinnamon topping. Add a swirl of whipped cream for an extra special treat. Once it’s cooled to room temperature, you can store the leftover apple topping in an air-tight container in the fridge.

steps.headline: Mix your pancake batter.
steps.description: Following the same recipe and instructions, make a batch of cinnamon pancake batter. Cinnamon roll pancakes combine the best parts of a pancake and a cinnamon roll, including the cinnamon swirl sauce and the icing.

steps.headline: Make the cinnamon sauce.
steps.description: For the cinnamon topping, you will need the brown sugar, the cinnamon, and 4 tablespoons (60 ml) of the melted butter or margarine. Whisk the cinnamon swirl ingredients together in a medium bowl, and then transfer it to a pastry bag. If you don’t have a pastry bag, transfer the mixture to a re-sealable plastic bag instead.

steps.headline: Prepare the icing.
steps.description: The remaining ingredients will be for the icing portion of the cinnamon roll pancakes, including the powdered sugar, milk, and the final tablespoon (15 ml) of melted butter. Whisk or beat these ingredients together in a medium bowl and set it aside. Add more milk (in very small increments) if the icing is too thick to drizzle.

steps.headline: Heat some oil in a frying pan.
steps.description: When it’s hot, pour the pancakes. Use one-quarter cup (60 ml) of batter as before. When the pancake begins to form bubbles in the center, get ready with your pastry bag of cinnamon sauce.

steps.headline: Create the cinnamon swirl.
steps.description: Start in the center of the pancake and squeeze the cinnamon sauce into the pancake in a swirl pattern. Continue cooking for another minute, until the bubbles start to pop. Flip the pancake over and cook for another two minutes, until the other side is golden brown. If you are using a plastic bag instead of a pastry bag, snip off one of the bottom corners of the bag and gently squeeze the cinnamon sauce out through the small hole.

steps.headline: Add the icing.
steps.description: When the pancake is cooked, drizzle it with a thin layer of icing. Alternatively, you can use a maple syrup drizzle instead to finish off the pancakes.

text:
Making Basic Cinnamon Pancakes Gather your supplies. To make these basic cinnamon pancakes, you will need your ingredients, a medium mixing bowl, a whisk or electric beaters, and a griddle or frying pan. Heat your frying pan. Add some extra oil or butter to the frying pan to lightly coat the bottom. Heat the oil over medium to high heat while you prepare the batter. Combine the liquid ingredients. In your mixing bowl, whisk together the wet ingredients, including the egg or egg replacer. Suitable egg replacers for this recipe include:
2 1/2 tablespoons (37.5 g) ground flaxseed mixed with 3 tablespoons (45 ml) water. 1/2 a mashed or pureed banana. 1 1/2 teaspoons (7.5 g) Ener-G Egg replacer mixed with 2 tablespoons (30 ml) water. Mix in the dry ingredients. Continue whisking or beating the liquids as you incorporate the dry ingredients. Don’t overmix the batter, or you could end up with chewy pancakes. A few lumps in the batter are acceptable. Pour the pancakes. Unless you have a large frying pan, make one pancake at a time. Pour a quarter-cup (60 ml) of batter into the frying pan and let it cook. When bubbles begin to form and cover the top side of the pancake, flip it over and cook for another two minutes. You want both sides to be golden brown. Add a bit more oil and repeat until all the pancakes are cooked. Serve immediately. If you want to wait until all the pancakes are cooked before serving, keep them warm in a warming drawer, on a plate covered in foil, or on a cookie sheet in a low oven. Making Apple Cinnamon Topping Gather your supplies. To make this apple and cinnamon pancake topping (which also functions as an apple pie filling or all-purpose dessert topping), you’ll need your apples, a sharp knife, and a large saucepan. Chop the apples. After coring and peeling the apples, cut them into small cubes. Set them aside as you prepare the sauce. Combine the sauce ingredients. Add the water, lemon juice, spices, sugar, maple syrup, and cornstarch to the saucepan. Heat on medium heat, stirring frequently. Once the sauce starts to bubble and thicken, continue stirring for another two minutes. Add the apples and vanilla. Turn the heat to low and stir to combine. Cover the saucepan and let the mixture cook on low for about 10 minutes, until the apples are soft. Let it cool. Once the apples are soft, remove the filling from the heat and allow it to cool for a few minutes. It doesn’t have to be room temperature, but you don’t want to burn any mouths! Serve over pancakes. Place one to two pancakes on a plate and cover each one with a few dollops of the apple cinnamon topping. Add a swirl of whipped cream for an extra special treat. Once it’s cooled to room temperature, you can store the leftover apple topping in an air-tight container in the fridge. Making Cinnamon Roll Pancakes Mix your pancake batter. Following the same recipe and instructions, make a batch of cinnamon pancake batter. Cinnamon roll pancakes combine the best parts of a pancake and a cinnamon roll, including the cinnamon swirl sauce and the icing. Make the cinnamon sauce. For the cinnamon topping, you will need the brown sugar, the cinnamon, and 4 tablespoons (60 ml) of the melted butter or margarine. Whisk the cinnamon swirl ingredients together in a medium bowl, and then transfer it to a pastry bag. If you don’t have a pastry bag, transfer the mixture to a re-sealable plastic bag instead. Prepare the icing. The remaining ingredients will be for the icing portion of the cinnamon roll pancakes, including the powdered sugar, milk, and the final tablespoon (15 ml) of melted butter. Whisk or beat these ingredients together in a medium bowl and set it aside. Add more milk (in very small increments) if the icing is too thick to drizzle. Heat some oil in a frying pan. When it’s hot, pour the pancakes. Use one-quarter cup (60 ml) of batter as before. When the pancake begins to form bubbles in the center, get ready with your pastry bag of cinnamon sauce. Create the cinnamon swirl. Start in the center of the pancake and squeeze the cinnamon sauce into the pancake in a swirl pattern. Continue cooking for another minute, until the bubbles start to pop. Flip the pancake over and cook for another two minutes, until the other side is golden brown. If you are using a plastic bag instead of a pastry bag, snip off one of the bottom corners of the bag and gently squeeze the cinnamon sauce out through the small hole. Add the icing. When the pancake is cooked, drizzle it with a thin layer of icing. Alternatively, you can use a maple syrup drizzle instead to finish off the pancakes.
